docs.snippet: Mark E. Koenig, the lead-off witness for the government against two former Enron chief executives, advanced the defense's argument with his testimony....
docs.lead_paragraph: At first glance, Mark E. Koenig appeared to be the perfect lead-off witness for the government in the criminal trial of Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, Enron's former chief executives. Clean-cut and articulate, Mr. Koenig, 50, ran investor relations for Enron and was a polished performer on Wall Street who was present at many of the crucial discussions, prosecutors say, where Mr. Skilling and Mr. Lay lied to the public about Enron's true financial condition in the days leading up to its spectacular collapse in late 2001.

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation, the bankrupt energy trading company, won court approval yesterday to pay as much as $45 million in bonuses to employees who are responsible for winding down the company's operations. Enron, which is selling its assets to rep...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation, the bankrupt energy trading company, won court approval yesterday to pay as much as $45 million in bonuses to employees who are responsible for winding down the company's operations. Enron, which is selling its assets to repay creditors, estimates that employees will ultimately receive about $16.8 million in bonuses. The company, which is based in Houston, will cease to exist once the asset sales are finished. Judge Arthur Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court in New York authorized the payments after the company said it needed to give employees an incentive to stay with Enron until the liquidation was complete. Enron estimates proceeds from the remaining asset sales will total $1.1 billion, which would mean employees would receive $16.8 million, Brian Rosen, Enron's lead bankruptcy lawyer, said. Judge Gonzalez authorized bonuses of as much as $45 million if the proceeds reach $3 billion or more.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lea Fastow, the wife of Enron's former chief financial officer, withdrew her guilty plea on criminal tax charges yesterday after a federal judge announced that he would not abide by the terms of her agreement with the government. The decision by Mrs. Fastow, a former assistant treasurer for Enron, came during a contentious sentencing hearing before Judge David Hittner of United States District Court in Houston. Judge Hittner refused to allow either the government or the defense to present oral arguments before he announced his position.
docs.abstract: Lea Fastow, wife of Enron's former chief financial officer Andrew Fastow and former assistant treasurer of company, withdraws her guilty plea after Federal Judge David Hittner announces he will not abide by terms of her agreement with government; Fastow now stands to be tried on all six felony counts in her indictment, rather than one charge agreed to in plea; Hittner schedules trial to begin in Brownsville, Tex, on June 2, which would make it first Enron case to go before jury by matter of two weeks; Fastow's withdrawal of her plea will have no direct effect on legal status of her husband, who has already pleaded guilty to fraud charges and has begun cooperating with government (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At New York University on Tuesday night, the redoubtable Muriel Siebert didn't mince words in assessing the current business environment. ''It's a case of total moral bankruptcy,'' said Ms. Siebert, the president and chairwoman of Muriel Siebert & Company, an investment firm. ''The Enron mess could not have happened without the banks, the lawyers and the accountants. I had no idea this was going on. But we should have known. The money was too fast and too vast.''

docs.lead_paragraph: The former treasurer of Enron is a subject of investigation for possible criminal charges in the company's collapse, according to court papers. The Justice Department has been investigating several Enron-related off-the-books partnerships used to hide $1 billion in losses. Prosecutors have been trying to seize the former treasurer's bank account, which contains $916,137, some of which is said to be ill-gotten gains from a partnership called Southampton.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sherron S. Watkins, the Enron vice president who warned top executives about the company's accounting problems months before its collapse, is leaving the company to work as a corporate governance consultant. The resignation of Ms. Watkins, who, despite her blunt criticism of Enron, remained an employee throughout the scandal, will be effective on Friday, said her lawyer, Philip H. Hilder.
